Key Findings

  • Blackpool Council's total spend analysed is £4068.9M across 7 financial years.
  • The BUDOCL department accounts for 28.2% of the total spend, with a budget of £1145.7M.
  • The top 5 departments by spend are BUDOCL (£1145.7M), Adult & Families (£307.9M), Children'S Services (£287.7M), ZBUDOCL (£268.5M), and CHISER (£258.2M).
  • The Community & Env Services department has a budget of £167.5M, accounting for 4.1% of the total spend.

Departmental Spending Breakdown

The spending data reveals that the BUDOCL department is the largest consumer of resources, with a budget of £1145.7M and accounting for 28.2% of the total spend. This is followed by Adult & Families and Children'S Services, with budgets of £307.9M and £287.7M respectively.

A closer look at the top 10 departments by spend reveals a diverse range of services, including ZBUDOCL (£268.5M), CHISER (£258.2M), and ADULTS (£226.8M). The Capital - Commnctn & Regen department also features in the top 10, with a budget of £147.7M.

Analysis and Context

The spending data provides valuable insights into the allocation of resources across different departments and services. The dominance of the BUDOCL department in terms of spend is notable, and warrants further analysis to understand the drivers behind this expenditure.

The presence of Adult & Families and Children'S Services in the top 3 departments by spend highlights the importance of social care services in Blackpool. The Community & Env Services department also features in the top 10, with a budget of £167.5M, indicating a significant investment in community and environmental initiatives.

Conclusion

In conclusion, the spending data reveals a complex and multifaceted picture of departmental spending in Blackpool. The dominance of the BUDOCL department, combined with the significant expenditure on social care services, highlights the need for further analysis and scrutiny of the council's spending priorities.

What You Can Do

  • Submit a Freedom of Information request to Blackpool Council about the specific spending priorities of the BUDOCL department.
  • Attend council committee meetings, which are open to the public, to gain a deeper understanding of the decision-making process behind departmental spending.
  • Check the council's published contracts register to identify the suppliers and contractors working with the council.
  • Write to your local councillor about your concerns regarding the allocation of resources across different departments and services.
  • Visit aidoge.co.uk to explore the full spending data and gain a more detailed understanding of the council's expenditure.
This article is based on Blackpool Council's published spending data covering 2019/20 to 2025/26. All figures are drawn directly from transactions published under the Local Government Transparency Code. Analysis by AI DOGE.
